questions.question: What is the primary rule regarding the `<main>` element on a single page?

answer_variants.answer: There must be only one visible `<main>` element per page, and it cannot be nested inside header, footer, or navigation elements.
The `<main>` element represents the dominant content of the `<body>` of a document. A document must not have more than one `<main>` element that does not have the `hidden` attribute.
It acts like the spotlight. You can only spotlight one main thing at a time. It tells the browser 'This is the actual page content', ignoring the sidebar and menu.

It maps to the ARIA role `main`. It allows keyboard users to 'Skip to Content' automatically. You can have multiple `<main>` tags in the DOM (e.g., for Single Page Apps), but only ONE can be visible/active at a time.

The restriction prevents Screen Readers from detecting multiple 'Main' landmarks, which confuses navigation. Structurally, it must be a top-level child of body (or close to it) and strictly strictly NOT a descendant of `<article>`, `<aside>`, `<footer>`, `<header>`, or `<nav>`.
A magazine has many articles, but only one 'Cover Story'. The `<main>` tag is that cover story.
1. Identify unique content (Post). 2. Identify shared content (Menu, Footer). 3. Wrap unique content in `<main>`. 4. Ensure only 1 exists.

The `<main>` element defines the unique content of the document. Crucially, it must be unique to the document (no duplicates) and must not be nested within non-unique regions like headers, footers, or sidebars.
Use it for the big content in the middle. Don't put it in the footer. Only use one per page.

The `<main>` landmark is central to accessible navigation. It informs user agents of the primary topic or functionality of the page. The HTML spec enforces a 'Single Visible Instance' rule to preserve the integrity of the 'Skip to Main Content' mechanism used by assistive technology.

questions.question: Can a page have multiple `<header>` or `<footer>` elements? Explain valid use cases.

answer_variants.answer: Yes, `<header>` and `<footer>` can be used multiple times if they are scoped to specific sections (e.g., an article's header vs. the page header).

The `<header>` and `<footer>` elements represent introductory or concluding content for their nearest ancestor sectioning content or sectioning root element. Therefore, multiple instances are valid if nested in different sections.
Yes! Just like a book has a main cover (Page Header), each chapter can also have a title and summary (Section Header). You can use them inside Articles too.

Common misconception is that they replace `<div id='header'>` (Page Header). While true, they also serve as heads/feet for `<article>`, `<section>`, or `<aside>` blocks. Example: A 'Card' component might have a `<header>` (Title) and `<footer>` (Action buttons).

Scope matters. A `<header>` as a direct child of `<body>` is the 'Page Banner' landmark. A `<header>` inside an `<article>` is just a grouping element for the h1/meta info of that article and does NOT create a landmark role unless specified. This prevents noise in the Accessibility Tree.
Think of a newsletter. The whole page has a Footer (Copyright). But each news story inside might have a Footer (Author Name). Both are valid 'Footers' in their own scope.
1. Page Level: `<header>Logo</header>`. 2. Content Level: `<article><header>Title</header></article>`. 3. Both are Valid.

Yes. `<header>` and `<footer>` are scoped to their sectioning container. While we typically have one main Site Header, each `<article>` or `<section>` can arguably have its own header/footer for internal organization without violating spec.
Yes, you can have a main header for the site and a small header for a blog post on the same page.

These elements are section-scoped. A `<header>` applies to its nearest parent complying with 'Flow Content' or 'Sectioning Content' rules. This allows meaningful semantic structures within components (like Cards or Modals) independent of the global page structure.

questions.question: What is the intended semantic usage of the `<aside>` element?

answer_variants.answer: It contains content that is tangentially related to the main content, such as sidebars, call-out boxes, or advertising.
The `<aside>` element represents a portion of a document whose content is only indirectly related to the document's main content. Asides are frequently presented as sidebars or call-out boxes.
It's for 'By the way...' information. Use it for things like 'Related Posts', 'Ads', or 'Author Bio'. It's stuff you can remove without breaking the main story.

If inside an `<article>`, the `<aside>` should contain data related to that specific article (e.g., Glossary). If outside, as a direct child of `<body>`, it represents global side content (e.g., Blog Sidebar, Navigation Drawer).

Assistive technology treats `<aside>` as a 'Complementary' landmark. Misuse (putting main content in aside) causes users to skip it. It implicitly separates the content flow, signalling that this data is auxiliary.
It's a whisper in a conversation. The main talk is the `<main>`. The `<aside>` is someone whispering 'Did you know...?' next to you.
1. Main text: 'How to code'. 2. Extra info: 'History of Code'. 3. Is it crucial? No. 4. Wrap 'History' in `<aside>`.

`<aside>` indicates tangentially related content. We use it for sidebars (navigation/ads) or inline pull-quotes. Ideally, the main content should remain fully understandable even if the `<aside>` is removed.
It's a sidebar. Use it for stuff that sits on the side of the page.

The `<aside>` element identifies content that separates from the main flow but remains contextually relevant. Semantically, it signals to parsers and ATs that this content is 'Complementary Landmarked'—supportive but secondary. Common for advertising containers, archives, or glossary definitions.

questions.question: Does the `<address>` tag allow efficient formatting of any physical address?

answer_variants.answer: No, `<address>` is strictly for providing Contact Information for the author/owner of the document, not just any random postal address.

The `<address>` element supplies contact information for its nearest `<article>` or `<body>` ancestor. It should strictly contain author details (email, physical address, social link). It is NOT for marking up arbitrary addresses (like a list of store locations).
Don't use it for every address you see! Only use it for the 'Contact Us' section or the author signature at the bottom of a post. It means 'Here is how to contact the person who wrote this'.
A common mistake is wrapping every postal address in `<address>`. This is semantically wrong. Use it only for context-owner contact info. Browsers often italicize it by default.

Scope rules: If inside `<body>`, it applies to the whole page (Site Owner). If inside `<article>`, it applies to that article (Post Author). It must not contain nested heading elements (`<h1>`), sections, or headers/footers.
It's the 'Business Card' attached to the file. You wouldn't attach a business card to a random building description.

1. Is this contact info? Yes. 2. Is it for the author/owner? Yes. 3. Use `
`. 4. Is it a random location? Use `

` or `

`.
The `<address>` tag is specifically for authorship contact details. It is misnamed; it should be thought of as `<contact-info>`. Using it for arbitrary physical locations is semantically incorrect.
It's for the author's contact info. not for putting a map address.

The `<address>` element has a narrow semantic scope: defining contact information for the nearest article or body element. It is forbidden to contain non-contact information or structural headings. Its use aids search engines in identifying authorship signals versus content data.

questions.question: What is the `<time>` tag and why is the `datetime` attribute important?

answer_variants.answer: It marks up times/dates for machines; `datetime` provides the standardized ISO-8601 format (e.g., `2023-10-31`) regardless of what is displayed.

The `<time>` element represents a specific period in time or duration. The `datetime` attribute provides a machine-readable value (ISO 8601), allowing the visible text content to be human-friendly (e.g., 'Yesterday').
Humans read 'Oct 5th'. Computers read '2023-10-05'. The `<time>` tag lets you show the human version to users, but give the computer version to Google via the attribute.
Google uses `<time>` for rich snippets (Event dates, Article publication dates). Without `datetime`, the parser has to guess the date format, which is ambiguous (Is 01/02 Jan 2nd or Feb 1st?).

It helps smart assistants (Siri/Calendar) parse events accurately. If strict ISO format is used (`YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss`), browsers can theoretically offer 'Add to Calendar' functionality. It creates a bridge between unstructured text and structured data.
Text is 'My Birthday'. `datetime` is the actual calendar entry. One is a label, the other is the data.
1. Display: 'Next Friday'. 2. Calculate: '2023-11-24'. 3. Tag: `<time datetime='2023-11-24'>Next Friday</time>`.

The `<time>` tag semantically defines a temporal event. The `datetime` attribute is mandatory for machine readability, normalizing vague terms like '2 hours ago' into strict ISO timestamps for SEO and crawlers.
It tells the browser that this text is a date. The attribute holds the real date code.

The `<time>` element allows for the encoding of temporal data. The `datetime` attribute resolves ambiguity by enforcing standard formats (ISO 8601). This disambiguation is critical for internationalization (US vs UK date formats) and for search engines indexing time-sensitive content like news or events.

questions.question: How do `<details>` and `<summary>` work together to create an interactive widget without JavaScript?

answer_variants.answer: `<details>` creates a collapsible container; `<summary>` defines the visible label that acts as the toggle button.

`<details>` implements a native disclosure widget. The content is hidden by default. `<summary>` acts as the legend/interactive trigger. Clicking `<summary>` toggles the `open` attribute on `<details>`.
It makes an accordion (open/close box). You put the title in `<summary>` (always visible). You put the hidden stuff in `<details>`. When you click the title, the hidden stuff appears.
This replaces basic JS accordions. It is semantic and accessible (Screen readers announce 'Expanded/Collapsed'). You can style the marker (triangle) using `::marker` or `list-style` CSS.

The `open` boolean attribute reflects the state. You can auto-open it by adding `open` in HTML. Crucially, the browser handles the ARIA states (`aria-expanded`) automatically. Use the `toggle` event in JS to listen for changes.
It's like a folded piece of paper. The `<summary>` is what's written on the outside fold. The content is what's inside. Clicking unfolds it.

1. Wrapper: `
`. 2. Toggle Button: `Click Me`. 3. Hidden Content: `

Peekaboo

`. 4. Result: Native Accordion.

Together they create a native 'Disclosure Widget'. `<summary>` is the button, `<details>` is the container. This provides built-in accessibility and keyboard interaction (Enter/Space to toggle) without writing a single line of JavaScript.
It creates a click-to-open box. Like an FAQ section where you click the question to see the answer.

The `<details>` element represents a disclosure widget from which the user can retrieve additional information. The first child `<summary>` provides the label and click handler. The User Agent manages the `open` attribute state automatically, providing a Javascript-free, accessible interactive pattern.

questions.question: Technically, what is the difference between `id` and `class` attributes?

answer_variants.answer: `id` must be unique per page and is a fragment identifier; `class` can be reused on multiple elements for grouping.

`id`: A unique identifier for the element within the document. Used for fragment navigation (#link), label association, and unique hooks. `class`: A space-separated list of classes, allowing multiple elements to be grouped for styling/scripting.
`id` is like a Social Security Number (only one person has it). `class` is like a Club Membership (many people can have it). You use ID for 'The One'. You use Class for 'The Group'.

Specificity: IDs have extremely high CSS specificity (1-0-0). Classes have medium specificity (0-1-0). Using IDs for styling is often discouraged because they are hard to override. `id` also creates a global variable in JS (legacy behavior).

IDs are strictly required for accessibility relationships (e.g., `aria-labelledby='id'`, `for='id'`). You cannot link a Label to a Class. Classes are purely for taxonomy and grouping. Duplicate IDs are invalid HTML and cause `getElementById()` to fail (returning only the first match).
ID is 'The President' (Only one). Class is 'Politician' (Many). You can style all Politicians easily. But if you want to target THE President, use ID.
1. Unique? -> `id`. 2. Multiple items? -> `class`. 3. Need to Link/Anchor? -> `id`. 4. Need to Style? -> `class` (preferred).

`id` implies uniqueness and is used for anchors, form bindings (`for`), and specific JS hooks. `class` implies categorization and is the standard for CSS styling to keep specificity, low and reusable.
ID is unique, Class is shared. Don't use ID for styling if you can help it.

The `id` attribute defines a unique identifier, crucial for DOM selection optimization (`getElementById`), fragment identifiers (URL hashes), and Accessibility association. The `class` attribute categorizes elements, principally for CSS selection and bulk DOM manipulation. Uniqueness of `id` is enforced by the HTML spec, though browsers handle duplicates gracefully but unpredictably.

questions.question: Explain the hierarchy of accessible naming: `aria-label` vs `aria-labelledby` vs `title` vs text content.

answer_variants.answer: `aria-labelledby` (highest priority) > `aria-label` > Native Label/Text > `title` (lowest priority).

The Accessible Name Calculation algorithm prioritizes `aria-labelledby` first. If missing, it checks `aria-label`. If missing, it checks native labeling (e.g., `<label>`). Finally, it falls back to the `title` attribute or inner text. `aria-label` overrides visible text.
It is a pecking order. If you give an element a nickname with `aria-labelledby`, the screen reader ignores everything else. `title` is the weakest—it usually gets ignored if anything else is present.

Use `aria-label` when no visible text exists (e.g., a search icon button). Use `aria-labelledby` to point to existing text on screen (e.g., a modal header acting as the modal's label). Avoid `title` as it has poor mobile support.

Critical Rule: `aria-label` overrides the element's inner text. `<button aria-label='Close'>X</button>` is read as 'Close'. `<button aria-label='Close'>Submit</button>` is read as 'Close', which is confusing. `aria-labelledby` is robust because it references DOM nodes, automatically updating if the referenced node updates.
It's like a nametag. `aria-labelledby` is pointing to a sign on the wall. `aria-label` is writing a new sticker. Text content is your face. `title` is a footnote.
1. Screen Reader checks `labelledby`. Found? Read it. 2. Checks `aria-label`. Found? Read it. 3. Checks content. Read it.

`aria-labelledby` takes precedence over everything. `aria-label` comes next, overriding native text. Native text/label is third. The `title` attribute is the last resort and generally discouraged due to UX inconsistency.
Aria stuff comes first. If you put an aria-label, the computer reads that and ignores the real text.

The Accessible Name Computation is a strict hierarchy. `aria-labelledby` (ID ref) wins, enabling referencing existing DOM text. `aria-label` (string) is second, allowing invisible labeling. Native semantics (like `<label for>`) are third. `title` is a weak fallback. Misusing this hierarchy (e.g., spamming aria-label on text-heavy elements) causes content duplication or erasure in the Accessibility Tree.

questions.question: What is the specific semantic meaning of the `<span>` and `<div>` tag?

answer_variants.answer: They have NO semantic meaning; they are generic containers used purely for styling (CSS) and scripting (JS) hooks.
`<div>` (Division) is a generic block-level container. `<span>` is a generic inline container. Neither tag conveys any meaning about its contents to the browser or assistive technology.
They are blank boxes. `div` is a big box (block). `span` is a small sticker (inline). You use them when no other specific tag (like `p`, `header`, `nav`) fits the job.

Use them as a last resort. If you can use `
`, `
`, or `

`, do so. `div` and `span` tells the browser 'There is nothing special about this text'. Overuse is called 'Divitis'.

Since they are semantically neutral, they do not affect the Accessibility Tree structure/outline. This makes them safe for layout wrappers (Flexbox/Grid parents) where you don't want to create unintended 'landmarks'. Ideally, they are used for visual styling hooks only.
They are clear plastic bags. You put stuff in them to carry it (style it), but the bag itself doesn't tell you what's inside (no meaning).
1. Need to group text? 2. Is it a list? No. 3. Is it a paragraph? No. 4. Is it a section? No. 5. Okay, use `<div>`.

They are semantically null elements. `<div>` is for block-grouping and `<span>` for text-grouping. We use them primarily for CSS application when no semantic alternative exists. They play no role in SEO or Accessibility beyond being nodes in the tree.
They mean nothing. They are just for when you need to put a class on something to style it.

The `div` and `span` elements represent children of 'Flow Content' and 'Phrasing Content' respectively, with zero semantic value. They are instrumental for visual presentation layers (CSS architecture) but contribute nothing to the Document Outline or Semantic Graph. Their ubiquity allows developers to separate style (CSS) from structure (Semantics) completely.

questions.question: What are 'Microdata' attributes (itemscope, itemtype, itemprop) used for?

answer_variants.answer: They implement Schema.org vocabulary directly in HTML, helping search engines understand objects (e.g., 'This Div is a Product with Price $5').

Microdata is a WHATWG HTML specification used to nest metadata within existing content. Attributes like `itemscope` (creates new item), `itemtype` (defines URL of vocabulary), and `itemprop` (properties) allow machine-readable structured data.
It's secret labels for Google. You tag a picture as 'Image', a number as 'Price', and a name as 'Product'. Google reads this and makes those fancy Profile or Product cards you see in search results.

It bridges HTML and knowledge graphs. While JSON-LD is now preferred by Google for Structured Data, Microdata is useful because it lives inline with the visible content, ensuring the data matches exactly what the user sees (preventing drift).

Detailed implementation: Add `itemscope` to container. Add `itemtype='https://schema.org/Person'`. Add `itemprop='name'` to the H1. This allows parsers to extract a JSON object: `{ '@type': 'Person', 'name': '...' }`. It is critical for Rich Snippets (Star ratings, Recipes).
HTML is text on a page. Microdata is highlighting that text and writing 'This is a phone number' in the margin for the robot.

1. Container: `
`. 2. Title: `

Avatar

`. 3. Director: `Cameron`.

Microdata attributes enable Structured Data injection according to Schema.org. They allow search engines to parse rich objects (Events, Products) directly from the DOM, driving Rich Snippets in SERPs. I typically prefer JSON-LD, but Microdata is the inline alternative.
It's deep SEO stuff. It labels parts of the page so Google knows 'This is a movie review' and 'This is the rating'.

Microdata provides a standardized syntax to annotate DOM elements with machine-readable tags. By using the `itemscope` and `itemtype` attributes, a node is designated as a semantic item defined by a vocabulary (usually Schema.org). `itemprop` attributes then key-value map the descendants. This allows the semantic web to parse the page as a dataset, not just a document.
